runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is about a class planting a garden for their community.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
of fresh juices at the market.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what Carla wants to start. (garden)
How does the class choose between the options of helping others in their community? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How does the garden help the community? Explain.
What do you think the neighbors will do at the party?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text describes the purpose of a city hall and how its an important place in a local community.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Which sports or after-school activities do you
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of a festival that might have posters hung up in a city hall. (Harvest Festival)
What is the history of city halls? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Summarize the different ways citizens can participate in events at their local, or nearby, city hall.
Not all places have city halls. Some have other kinds of buildings where decisions are made. Which government buildings are in your area?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (period) and 2 (question mark). Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end). Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle contains clues that will help students identify the missing word.

For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the second riddle. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle. Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all words with
spellings in the riddles and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about taxes and what taxes pay for.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
is to give a job to someone.
many teachers and other staff, or workers.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the first example of something that taxes pay for. (army)
What are some things that state governments tax? Find the sentences that answer this question.
The government employs many people. How do government workers benefit from taxes?
Do you think it is fair for citizens to pay taxes? What would happen if citizens did not pay taxes?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts. For example, as you read sentence 5, pause briefly after
. Point out that each group of words relates to one idea in the sentence. Have students echo your phrasing.

Read the title. Explain that this shows what taxes are used for by displaying, or showing, a pie chart. The pie chart shows how much of Greenfields tax money goes to each service. The pie chart has colors and percentages. The percent is on each wedge. Each wedge identifies a service to show what the taxes pay for.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the pie chart.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the pie chart.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a class trip to the Statue of Liberty.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is something that represents, or stands for, an idea.
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the teacher leading the class trip. (Mr. Clark)
Who is the special lady Mr. Clark wants his students to meet? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What is the statue a symbol of? Can it be a symbol of more than one idea? Explain.
How do you think the students felt about Mr. Clarks surprise? What makes you think so?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a nonfiction text about different community jobs. Have students identify the job shown in each photo.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
to builders of houses? Chefs, who cook food? Artists?
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find three things that mail carriers bring to people. (letters, cards, packages)
Why are firefighters important community workers? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are teachers, bus drivers, mail carriers, police officers, and firefighters essential to our community? Explain.
Which job from this text would you like to have? Why?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
